Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Directions for Undergraduate Education in Mechanics of Solids

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Undergraduate education in solid mechanics influences the preparation and success of engineering majors in some of the engineering disciplines with the largest enrollments, including: mechanical, civil, and aerospace. Improvements in undergraduate education in this important field will lead to graduates who are better equipped to address the increasing breadth of materials used in engineering applications. Therefore, this project is conducting a two-day workshop on the future directions for undergraduate curricula in mechanics of solids, involving redesigning content, improving student education, and teaching of courses. Participants include experts in mechanics of solids, faculty members who have pioneered new teaching approaches, and recently graduated students (undergraduate and graduate) who are in the workforce and academia. Approximately 40 workshop participants are exploring new directions in designing and teaching courses in the area of mechanics of solids.

The workshop is addressing the following topics:
- Growing Application of Polymeric, Biological, and Geological Materials
- Promising Approaches to Teaching
- Key Differences between Behavior of New and Traditional Materials
- Missed Connections between Failure Modes and Stress and Strain
- Packed Courses

Participation of a large number of key figures in education in mechanics of solids from both research and educational perspectives is generating increased visibility of the workshop. The outcomes and results are being published in journals to further expand the influence of the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mechanics of solids, in which engineering students learn how materials fail and how engineers can evaluate likelihood of failure in a variety of situations, is a core subject in many engineering programs. Most textbooks on the subject emphasize the behavior of metals in situations where the object deforms (i.e., changes shape) very little; however, many current and future applications require failure analysis for materials other than metals in situations where the object deforms significantly. Examples include car tires, plastic garbage bags, asphalt runways, Kevlar structural components, blood vessel and heart walls, and composite airplane structures, e.g., the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. Materials in these and other important technological applications behave and fail very differently from metals. Also, research-based instructional approaches have been developed and demonstrated considerable potential for improved learning. Although these observations have been made for several years, few instructional changes, content or teaching approaches, have occurred broadly in programs across the country in this core undergraduate engineering subject. There are numerous potential changes that could be made in the content covered in the subject as well as how the subject is taught, but few broad, generally implemented variations from practices in the 1950s and 1960s have occurred.

In response, the project leaders organized a two-day workshop that brought together about 30 faculty members from across the country to explore ways. In order that the workshop outcomes might represent input from many different types of faculty members, many different types of engineering programs, and many different areas of the country, broad participation was sought. Workshop participants included faculty members and scientists at industrial research laboratories recognized for their contributions to research in this area and faculty members who are noted for their innovative approaches to teaching the subject. Participants from across the country attended the workshop. Workshop participants commented on how much they enjoyed constructive conversations about their favorite subject with colleagues from many different perspectives and backgrounds.

In the workshop report, there was clear consensus about what constitutes the fundamental/core subject matter of a basic sequence of courses in the mechanics of solids. As expected, with regard to the non-core material there were numerous different subject areas that were suggested for inclusion in the course that reflected the individual pedagogical and research interests of the participants. But even in the non-core areas, the level of consensus at the end of the workshop was surprising. Also, there was general consensus concerning material that is currently a part of the curriculum that was felt as outdated or not relevant to the current needs.

Core content, identified as the three pillars of mechanics, was:

(i)                  Kinematics: Geometry of deformation: How can students describe geometrically how the material deforms? Describing how an object changes shape can get to be very complicated mathematically, even though students can sketch and see it. In view of the widespread use of polymers and the importance of understanding the response of biological tissues, students should have some capability to describe large deformations, especially visually. Activities that challenge students to describe large deformations that emphasize appropriate conceptual understanding of the geometry of deformation need to be developed and widely used. Some examples were offered at the workshop, and an archive of activities appropriate for undergraduate mechanics of materials courses might be a potential future project.
